items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of expected persistent rainfall or snowfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 04/01/25, into tomorrow morning, 05/01/25.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.  
We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
It is possible that river levels will begin rising overnight, 04/01/25 and into tomorrow morning, 05/01/25.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 2:00 PM on 05/01/2025.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast over the weekend and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are within banks, but remain high, on the River Windrush, particularly in the Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. 

This morning, 04/01/2025, is forecast to be mainly dry. Widespread rain with a chance of snow is forecast from this afternoon and overnight into Sunday. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days and may rise again in response to forecast rainfall. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall or snowfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 04/01/2025, into tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
It is possible that river levels will begin rising overnight, 04/01/2025, and into tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Kites Hardwick river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall or snowfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 04/01/2025, into tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
It is possible that river levels will begin rising overnight, 04/01/2025, and into tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible as the rivers Yeo, Cam, and tributaries are rising, due to the heavy overnight rain.
We anticipate river overtopping and flooding of riverside land, roads and buildings, particularly in and downstream of the Sherborne area, throughout today.
More rain is forecast today, so there is a risk of further flooding overnight into tomorrow, with this Flood Alert remaining in force.
We are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
Rising river levels throughout the evening and early tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow. We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are now falling at the Rodington and Tern-Walcot River gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

Further rainfall and possibly snow is expected over the weekend, which may cause river levels to rise. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00am on Sunday 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Flooding is possible from 10:30am today, 5 January 2025. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Mole with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Horley. Further rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.

We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 8pm today, 5 January 2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels throughout the evening may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

20mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill early on Sunday morning (05/01/2025). Minor flooding could affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and a small number of gardens in Crowhurst. From 12:00 on 05/01/2025, a small amount of water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. River levels in Crowhurst should initially begin to fall by 15:00 on 05/01/2025. However, further periods of rain are possible on Sunday and Monday, which could cause river levels to rise again, or slow the fall. River levels in Bulverhythe will remain higher than normal until midweek. River levels will hopefully not rise significantly higher than they were at New Years, and property flooding is not currently expected. However, as a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 on 05/01/2025.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Temple Mill river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall or snowfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 04/01/2025, into tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
It is possible that river levels will begin rising overnight, 04/01/2025, and into tomorrow morning, 05/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this morning 05/01/2025 due to heavy rain and snow melt, property flooding is not expected at this time. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Bourne at Hadlow and Little Mill.
Flooding is possible throughout Sunday into Monday as river levels rise due to heavy rainfall.  Rain is expected to continue throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

We anticipate river overtopping and flooding of riverside land and roads throughout today.
More rain is forecast today, so there is a risk of further flooding overnight into tomorrow, with this Flood Alert potentially remaining in force.
We are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
Rising river levels throughout the day may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Flooding is possible from 09:00 AM on 05/01/2025.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and refer to local authority website for road closures.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River is high and rising. Throughout the course of the night, heavy rain (23mm) has been recorded in Romsey. This is a large amount of rain in a short period of time. From 10:00 this morning 05/01/2025, the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the Mill building at East Wellow. Further rain is forecast over the next 6 hours. We expect the river will rise at least until 19:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025. Given the amount of rain currently affecting the area, by 18:00 it is it is possible that a Flood Warning will be issued for onset of isolated property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on Monday 06/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
Flooding is possible as the river Brue, and its tributaries are rising, due to the heavy overnight rain.
We anticipate river overtopping and flooding of riverside land, roads and buildings, particularly in the Lovington 
area, throughout today.
More rain is forecast today, so there is a risk of further flooding overnight into tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Prepare now to keep you, precious items, and your property safe. Install flood protection, gather 
emergency supplies, pack a bag containing essentials and look out for further warnings.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this morning 05/01/2025 due to heavy rain and snow melt, property flooding is not expected at this time. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly around Lingfield, Haxted and Edenbridge.
Flooding is possible throughout Sunday into Monday as river levels rise due to heavy rainfall.  Rain is expected to continue throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

25mm of rain has already been recorded at Cowbeech. Another 10mm of rain is possible before midday on Sunday (05/01/2025). More rain fell than was expected. Flooding will continue to affect fields and rural roads. From 08:30 on 05/01/2025, flooding will approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 11:00 on 05/01/2025, flooding will also approach properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 13:00 on 05/01/2025, flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane and the Old Clergy House in Alfriston. Only showers are forecast on Sunday afternoon and Monday. Rivers should begin to fall by 21:00 on 05/01/2025 in Hellingly, and 09:00 on 06/01/2025 in Alfriston. Flood impacts could remain until Tuesday 07/01/2025. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 05/01/2025.

The River Uck is high and rising. 25mm of rain has been recorded at Buxted early on Sunday morning. This is a lot of rain in a short period of time. Another 10mm of rain is possible before midday Sunday. Minor flooding will already be affecting fields. From 08:00 05/01/2025 flooding could affect gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub. In Uckfield, areas affected could include Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk. Flood water will also affect fields and gardens at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Only showers are forecast Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 05/01/2025, and return nearer to normal on Monday. River levels could end up similar to October and November 2024. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 05/01/2025

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the East Devon area. This has meant that the Rivers Clyst, Culm, and their tributaries are now rising. 
We expect rivers to remain high throughout today though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Sunday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Gloucester River gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.

Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.75 to 3m on Saturday evening, 04/01/25, Haw Bridge 3.5 to 4m on Saturday evening, Sandhurst 2.5 to 3m Saturday evening, Gloucester 2.5 to 3m on Saturday evening.   

Further rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated by 11am on Sunday 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hellingly and Horsebridge on the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high and rising. 25mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech Saturday evening and Sunday morning. Another 5mm of rain is predicted before midday on Sunday. From 10:00 05/01/2025, flooding will affect fields, rural roads including Hammer Lane near Cowbeech, and properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly and at Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 14:00 05/01/2025, flooding will also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, including gardens and properties on those roads. Only showers are forecast Sunday afternoon and Monday. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly should begin to fall by 17:00 05/01/2025. The Bull River through Hellingly should begin to fall by 23:00 05/01/2025, returning nearer to normal on Monday afternoon 06/01/2025. River levels could peak higher than seen at the end of November 2024. Some roads may become impassable, including Mill Road and Church Road. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 05/01/2025.

The River Adur is high and rising, following 20mm of rain overnight on Saturday into Sunday morning. From 08:00 today (Sunday 05/01/2025), flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. Further periods of rain are forecast today (Sunday 05/01/2025) which will likely cause the River Adur to rise again, or slow the fall. River levels should peak similar to New Years. Property flooding is not currently expected. Some roads may become impassable, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise area from Horsmonden to Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this morning 05/01/2025 due to heavy rain and snow melt, property flooding is not expected at this time. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads close to river in and around Collier Street.
Flooding is possible throughout Sunday into Monday as river levels rise due to heavy rainfall.  Rain is expected to continue throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising. 20mm of rain has been recorded at Ardingly Saturday night. Another 5mm of rain is expected before midday Sunday. Only minimal flood impacts are expected near Ardingly. From 11:00 05/01/2025 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and  gardens of properties on Sloop Lane. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be affected. Flooding will likely affect the Anchor Inn and Anchor Lane, and might affect gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills road could become impassable. Only showers are predicted Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 05/01/2025 near Ardingly, but not until Monday morning in Barcombe. Flood impacts could remain until Monday evening. River levels will end up higher than at the New Year. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Barcombe Mills road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 05/01/2025

items.message:
Flooding is possible from now and throughout today, Sunday 5th January. 

Heavier than forecast rain has fallen during the night and rivers are rising. River levels suggest there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. 

We expect rivers to remain high throughout Sunday, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast. 

Take care near areas of concern and avoid walking or driving through floodwater.  Monitor your local weather conditions and check river levels on the gov.uk website. 

Further rain forecast during the day, which may result in additional Flood Alerts being issued. 

We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. 

This message will be updated by 4pm on Sunday or earlier if the situation changes.

Flooding is possible on Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Teign area. This has meant that the River Teign is now rising. 
We expect the river to remain high throughout today.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Sunday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:
Flooding is possible as the River Tone and its tributaries have risen, due to the heavy overnight rain.
We anticipate river overtopping and flooding of riverside land and roads throughout today.
More rain is forecast today, so there is a risk of further flooding overnight into tomorrow, with this Flood Alert potentially remaining in force.
We are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

Sunday afternoon's tide at 14:45 on 05/01/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Westerly Force 6 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.32 m. The total forecast tide is 5.77 metres Chart Datum (2.72 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach, and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday's early morning tide at 03:00 on 06/01/2025 is forecast to be 29 cm higher (3.01 mAOD). Minor flood impacts are again expected over Monday's early morning tide, with the potential to experience a little more flood water than recent days. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 19:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Lyd, River Thrushel

items.message:
Flooding is possible from now and throughout today, Sunday 5th January. 

Heavier than forecast rain has fallen during the night and rivers are rising. River levels suggest there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. 

We expect rivers to remain high throughout Sunday, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast. 

Take care near areas of concern and avoid walking or driving through floodwater.  Monitor your local weather conditions and check river levels on the gov.uk website. 

Further rain forecast during the day, which may result in additional Flood Alerts being issued. 

We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. 

This message will be updated by 4pm on Sunday or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Highest tide level is expected to be at Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach at 10:10 AM on 05/01/2025. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths. Further flooding is possible tomorrow evening at the next high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Strong winds and low pressure are expected to increase hazardous coastal conditions due to sea spray and wave overtopping. Increased risk is possible tomorrow, Sunday 05/01/2025, between 09:30am and 12:30pm. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston, particularly exposed parts of the coastline. We are closely monitoring the situation will issue flood warnings if necessary. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 1pm on Sunday 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Sunday morning the 5th of January.  High water at Plymouth is at 09:12am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Spring tides are forecast to cause flooding between 8:12am and 10:12am.
Wave heights of up to 4m and Force 6 south-westerly winds will cause localised overtopping along exposed sections of the coastline.
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas of Plymouth Sound and along the estuaries.
Waterside locations and roads along the estuary may be flooded.  Do not walk or drive through flood water.
Coastal conditions should ease for Sunday evening’s high tide; however, further flood alerts will be issued if necessary.
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 11am on Sunday, or sooner if the situation changes.
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.71 mAOD.  Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.4 and 0.5 metres above tide table level.  Moderate force 6 south-westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 4m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head

Wave heights of up to 4m and Force 6 south-westerly winds will cause localised overtopping along exposed sections of the coastline.

Locations particularly at risk include low lying coastal communities.

Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.

Coastal conditions should ease for Sunday evening’s high tide; however, further flood alerts will be issued if necessary.

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.49 mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.4 and 0.5 metres above tide table level. Moderate Force 6 south-westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 4m are forecast over the high tide.

Spring tides are forecast to cause flooding between 07:43am and 09:43am.

Wave heights of up to 4m and Force 6 south-westerly winds will cause localised overtopping along exposed sections of the coastline.

High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 4:30 AM on 05/01/2025. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. Further flooding is possible tomorrow afternoon at the next high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are now falling at the Cae Howel river gauge  following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 

Observed peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 4.68m on Wednesday afternoon; Cae Howel peaked at 5.12m Friday morning 03/01/25.

Flood water could be deep and fast flowing and therefore pose a risk to life. Further rainfall and possibly snow is expected over the weekend, which may cause river levels to rise. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Sunday 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Leek and Upper Tean river gauges as a result of expected persistent rain or snowfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 04/01/25, into tomorrow morning, 05/01/25. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   
We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
It is possible that river levels will begin rising overnight, 04/01/25, into tomorrow morning, 05/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation, and our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Dee.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. We are not expecting to issue Flood Warnings.  

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke and Upton upon Severn. Install property level protection if required.   

Predicted peaks:- Bewdley 3.3 to 3.5m on Saturday morning, 04/01/25, Worcester 3.25 to 3.5 on Saturday afternoon, Diglis 2.6 to 2.9m on Saturday afternoon, Kempsey Yacht Club 4.6 to 5.1m on Saturday evening, Saxons Lode 3.5 to 4m on Saturday evening.   

Further rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated by 11am on Sunday, 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

Flows in the Lower River Itchen at Mansbridge are high and increasing. In the last 14 hours, 22mm of rain has been recorded at Portswood. High tide at Southampton is expected at 14:30 and 16:15 on 05/01/2025 and is forecast at 4.85 metres Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD). For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing to sea. This may cause the river to flood the access road and affect the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Footpath flooding may also affect Riverside Park. Further rainfall (up to 15mm) is expected throughout Sunday 05/01/2025. Flow in the river will remain high and may increase after high tide and could cause flooding impacts over the next high tide forecast at 03:00 on Monday 06/01/2025. We continue to monitor the forecast and will remove reported blockages from the river. We recommend closing the defence gates around the pub at least an hour before high tide. This Flood Alert will be updated by 21:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025.

River levels are rising at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 4.6 to 5.1m on Saturday evening 4th January 2025. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11am on Sunday 5th January 2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This alert has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

River levels remain high but are now falling at the Crew Green, Montford, Welsh Bridge and Buildwas river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. 

Observed Peaks:- Crew Green peaked at 6.24m on Thursday morning, 02/01/25. Montford peaked at 5.72m on Thursday evening, 02/01/25, Welsh Bridge peaked at 3.24m on Friday morning 03/01/25, Buildwas peaked at 4.29m overnight on Saturday morning, 04/01/25.

Further rainfall and possibly snow is expected over the weekend, which may cause river levels to rise. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid roads that may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00am on Sunday 05/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible during the early hours of Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Torridge area. This has meant that the River Torridge is now rising. 
The main areas of concern are Weare Giffard and Annery Kiln, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. 
We expect the river to remain high throughout today and warnings may need to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated during Sunday.

High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Highest tide level is expected to be at Lyme Regis, Charmouth, Seatown, West Bay, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater and Burton Bradstock at 10:00 AM on 05/01/2025. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths. After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 12:00 noon on 05/01/2025.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Biss, Paxcroft Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Westbury Road (A363) at Yarnbrook, Hawkeridge Road at Horse Bridge, Shallow Wagon Lane at Heywood and West Ashton Road at Trowbridge.

Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Torridge (Lower) from Dolton to Bideford, including Taddiport and Weare Giffard
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Torridge area. This has meant that the River Torridge is now rising. 
Properties and low lying areas in Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads), will start to flood first from around 06:00 on Sunday. River levels will be at their highest between 06:45 and 09:00.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Taw (Middle) from Taw Bridge to Newnham Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible during the early hours of Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Taw area. This has meant that the River Taw is now rising. 
Properties and low lying areas along the River Taw will start to flood first from around 05:30am on Sunday. 
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising, following 20mm of rain overnight on Saturday into Sunday morning. Minor flood impacts could affect isolated properties and farm buildings near Slaughter Bridge on the Coolham Road, as well as fields and rural roads between Coolham, and Henfield and fields near Church Close, Shipley. Further periods of rain are forecast today (Sunday 05/01/2025) which will likely cause the River Adur to rise again, or slow the fall. River levels should peak similar to New Years. Property flooding is not currently expected. Some roads may be affected by flood water, including the Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected due to heavy rain and snow melt, property flooding is not expected at this time.
Flooding is expected from 7 AM on 05/01/2025.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Brede, particularly around Winchelsea and low lying land and roads along the River Tillingham between Broad Oak and Rye.
Flooding is possible throughout Sunday into Monday as river levels rise due to heavy rainfall.  Rain is expected to continue throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St John's Station is high and rising. Heavy and intense rain has fallen with 24 mm in 10 hours recorded at Ryde. This is a large amount in a short period of time. From 07:30 this morning (Sunday 05/01/2025), water will begin to flow across the railway tracks, upstream of St John's Station. Rain will continue to affect the area over the next 6 hours with up to 10mm of rain expected. Water levels are unlikely to fall until 10:00, with flood impacts continuing until then. We will keep the river free of reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please consider moving vehicles from depots located next to the river and railway line. This Flood Alert will be updated by 21:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025.

The water level in the River Medina at Blackwater and Shide is high and rising. In the last 11 hours, 23mm of rain has been recorded in Cowes. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. From 06:30 this morning 05/01/2025, out of bank flooding will affect land, gardens and possibly roads at Blackwater, especially at Blackwater Hollow on the A3020 near Mill Farm and at Sandy Lane. At 07:00, the river will become very high at St George's Way, Shide. Rain will continue to affect the area over the next 6 hours with up to 10mm expected. Water levels are unlikely to fall until 13:00 05/01/2025 with flood impacts continuing until then. In the next 2 hours we may issue a flood warning for onset of property flooding from the river. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. If you have it, we would encourage residents to install flood protection now. This Flood Alert will be updated at 21:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 32mm of rain has fallen at Wroxall. This is a significant amount in a short time. In the next 8 hours, water will be ponded on low lying land adjacent to the river throughout the river valley. Road, cycle track and footpath flooding is expected. At Langbridge and Alverstone Road Bridge, the river will be close to the top of the river bank. Property flooding is not currently expected. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown may occur from early Monday morning 06/01/2025. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Light rain is forecast over the next 7 hours. At Alverstone, the river will rise until approximately 17:00 on Sunday afternoon 05/01/2025. At Sandown, levels will not peak until Monday morning 06/01/2025. We've checked Bembridge sluice is operating normally. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens from flooding are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated at 11:00 on Monday 06/01/2025.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this morning 05/01/2025 due to heavy rain and snow melt, property flooding is not expected at this time. 
Flooding is possible throughout Sunday into Monday as river levels rise due to heavy rainfall.  Rain is expected to continue throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have slowly started to recede. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. There is rain forecast for 1st Jan 2025.

After New Year's Day the forecast is for high pressure to build over the next 3-5 days which should see groundwater levels continue to fall.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 7/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are slowly rising at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, the rate of rise has slowed as a result of recent more settled weather. 

Groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week. We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 07/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley as a result of recent settled weather. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again following prolonged rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 07/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and remain relatively stable after a week of dry weather. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, the level is very close to causing cellar flooding impacts to a small number of properties. It is also very close to reducing the ability of septic tanks in Old Alresford to operate effectively. Tomorrow (01/01/2025), unsettled weather is forecast to move over Hampshire bringing between 10 and 20mm of rain. From Thursday (02/01/2025) to Saturday (04/01/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. If the heaviest rain in the forecast affects the area, then it is possible that groundwater levels will rise high enough for cellar flooding and septic tank impacts to occur. We continue to monitor the forecast. We advise residents to remain prepared for flooding impacts this winter. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 07/01/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday the 8th of January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday the 8th of January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton as a result of recent rainfall. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue slowly rising over the next few weeks and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 07/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Lukely Brook at Newport is high and rising. In the last 11 hours, 24mm of rain has fallen at Carisbrooke. This is a large volume in a short period of time. Currently, the river is near to bank full. From 06:30 this morning (05/01/2025) flooding may affect land at Vicarage Walk. We are not expecting impacts from the river at Carisbrooke. The river may also come out of bank from Old Westminster Lane to Hunnycross Way, flooding footpaths. Further heavy rain is forecast over the next 6 hours. If levels continue to rise, in the next 1 to 2 hours we may issue a Flood Warning, for onset of property flooding directly from the river. Vulnerable areas are Old Westminster Lane, and the Aquatics Centre at Vicarage Walk near Foxes Road. Our operational contractors will ensure the river is kept free of any reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. At Vicarage Walk, we encourage residents living nearest the river to take action to protect their property. This Flood Alert will be updated at 21:00 on 05/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk include the Corfe Castle and Swanage areas. Further flooding is possible throughout the morning as river levels are expected to remain high due to further rainfall. We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Danes Stream is very high. In the last 13 hours, 27mm of rain has been recorded at Stem Lane. This is a significant amount in a short time. Milford Dam has operated correctly to reduce the amount of water flowing to Milford on Sea. However, the water level in the village is very high and some footpath flooding is occurring. Gardens at Milford on Sea High Street may also be affected. No impacts are expected at Ashley. Following high tide this afternoon (Sunday 05/01/2025), the level in the river should begin to reduce. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please keep away from the riverside footpaths in Milford on Sea, especially at Milford Bridge opposite Lucerne Road during Sunday 05/01/2025. If footpaths are flooded it will be difficult to see where the edge of the main river channel is. This Flood Alert will be updated at 12:00 on Monday 06/01/2025.
